4 Chapter 1: Introduction to Statistics Statistics exists because the world is uncertain. Every day we make decisions without knowing the future. Will tomorrow’s sales increase? Will it rain? Will a patient recover? Will a machine fail? The world contains variation, randomness, and unpredictability. Statistics gives us tools to reason under uncertainty. 4.1 Why Does Uncertainty Exist? Even if we repeat the same action twice, results can differ. For example: Two students study equal hours but score differently. A marketing campaign works in one city but fails in another. A model performs well on training data but poorly on new data. This variability is the starting point of statistics. Statistics exists because outcomes are not perfectly predictable. 4.2 What Is Data? Data is recorded information about the world. It can represent: Sales numbers Heights of students Temperature readings Website clicks Medical test results But raw data alone has no meaning. Example: sales <- c(120, 135, 150, 98, 175, 142) sales ## [1] 120 135 150 98 175 142 These are just numbers. Without context, they tell us nothing. Statistics gives structure and meaning to data. 4.3 Why Raw Data Is Not Enough Imagine you are a business manager. You receive 10,000 rows of customer transaction data. What do you want to know? Average purchase amount Most common product category Seasonal trends Whether marketing increased revenue Raw data does not answer these. We need methods to: Summarize Analyze Interpret Draw conclusions That system of methods is statistics. 4.4 What Is Statistics? Statistics is the science of learning from data. More formally: It is the discipline concerned with collecting, organizing, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting data to make decisions under uncertainty. Statistics has two major branches: Descriptive Statistics Inferential Statistics 4.5 Descriptive vs Inferential Statistics 4.5.1 Descriptive Statistics Descriptive statistics summarizes the data we already have. Examples: Mean (average) Median Standard deviation Charts and graphs Example in R: mean(sales) ## [1] 136.6667 sd(sales) ## [1] 26.27293 These numbers describe only the observed data. They do not generalize beyond it. 4.5.2 Inferential Statistics Inferential statistics goes further. It asks: “If this sample looks like this, what can we say about the entire population?” Example: We survey 200 customers. Can we say something about all 50,000 customers? Inferential statistics allows us to: Estimate unknown quantities Test hypotheses Measure uncertainty Build predictive models This is where probability becomes essential. 4.6 Population vs Sample Suppose an e-commerce company has: 1,000,000 customers (population) We survey: 2,000 customers (sample) Why not ask all 1,000,000? Because: It is expensive It is slow It may be impractical Statistics allows us to use samples to understand populations. This idea is the foundation of modern data science. 4.7 Where Statistics Is Used in Business Statistics is everywhere in business. 4.7.1 Marketing A/B testing Conversion rate optimization 4.7.2 Finance Risk modeling Portfolio optimization 4.7.3 Operations Demand forecasting Inventory control 4.7.4 Healthcare Drug effectiveness testing Survival analysis 4.7.5 Technology Recommendation systems Fraud detection Without statistics, decisions become guesses. 4.8 Statistics vs Probability These two are closely related but different. Probability: Starts with a known model Predicts outcomes Statistics: Starts with data Infers the model Example: Probability: “What is the chance of getting heads?” Statistics: “Based on 100 flips, is this coin biased?” Probability moves forward. Statistics moves backward. Machine learning combines both. 4.9 Case Study: Online Retail Company Imagine an online store observing daily sales: daily_sales <- c(120, 150, 130, 160, 200, 170, 180) mean(daily_sales) ## [1] 158.5714 The average daily sales is around 158. But management asks: Is this stable? Is there growth? Is advertising working? Can we predict next month? Now we need: Variability analysis Trend analysis Hypothesis testing Regression modeling Statistics transforms data into strategy. 4.10 Statistics in Machine Learning Machine learning is built on statistical ideas. Examples: Linear regression = statistical regression model Logistic regression = probability model Naive Bayes = conditional probability Gaussian distributions = normal distribution theory Overfitting = variance concept Bias-variance tradeoff = statistical error decomposition Even neural networks rely on: Optimization Loss functions Probability distributions If statistics is weak, machine learning becomes memorization without understanding. Strong statisticians become strong ML engineers. 4.11 The Big Picture Statistics answers four fundamental questions: What happened? Why did it happen? What will happen next? How confident are we? It provides tools to reason under uncertainty. It replaces guesswork with structured thinking. 4.12 What You Will Learn in This Book In the next chapters, we will explore: Data types and measurement scales Sampling techniques Descriptive measures Probability theory Distributions Estimation and confidence intervals Hypothesis testing Regression and correlation Time series analysis Non-parametric methods Advanced statistical concepts used in AI Each concept will include: Intuition Real-world application Mathematical explanation R implementation Machine learning connection 4.13 Final Thought Statistics is not about numbers. It is about understanding uncertainty. Once you understand uncertainty, you understand risk. Once you understand risk, you make better decisions.

5 Chapter 2: Data and Data Collection Data is the raw material of statistics. Without good data, even the best statistical methods fail. 5.1 What Is Data? Data is recorded information about the world. Examples: Daily sales numbers Temperature readings Customer reviews Blood pressure measurements Website clicks Understanding what data represents is the first step toward correct analysis. 5.2 Types of Data There are two broad categories of data. 5.2.1 Qualitative (Categorical) Data This describes qualities or categories. Examples: Gender Product category Blood type Customer satisfaction level Example in R: category <- c("Electronics", "Clothing", "Electronics", "Groceries") table(category) ## category ## Clothing Electronics Groceries ## 1 2 1 This data describes groups, not numerical measurements. 5.2.2 Quantitative (Numerical) Data This represents measurable quantities. Examples: Sales amount Height Weight Revenue Example: sales <- c(120, 135, 150, 98, 175) mean(sales) ## [1] 135.6 Quantitative data allows mathematical operations. 5.3 Levels of Measurement The level of measurement determines what type of analysis is valid. 5.3.1 Nominal Scale Categories without order. Example: - Colors - Blood type You cannot compute an average of colors. 5.3.2 Ordinal Scale Categories with order but no fixed difference. Example: - Satisfaction: Low, Medium, High - Education level We know the order, but differences are not measurable. 5.3.3 Interval Scale Ordered and measurable but no true zero. Example: - Temperature in Celsius 0°C does not mean “no temperature.” 5.3.4 Ratio Scale Ordered, measurable, true zero. Example: - Income - Height - Sales revenue Most statistical methods require ratio scale data. 5.4 Population vs Sample 5.4.1 Population Entire group of interest. Example: All customers of an e-commerce company. 5.4.2 Sample Subset of population used for analysis. Example: Surveying 2,000 customers from 1 million. Why use samples? Cheaper Faster Practical Statistics allows us to generalize from sample to population. 5.5 Census vs Sampling 5.5.1 Census Collect data from entire population. Example: National census. 5.5.2 Sampling Collect data from a subset. Most businesses use sampling. Sampling is powerful — but dangerous if done incorrectly. 5.6 Sampling Techniques 5.6.1 Simple Random Sampling Every individual has equal chance. Example simulation: set.seed(123) population <- 1:10000 sample_data <- sample(population, 100) head(sample_data) ## [1] 2463 2511 8718 2986 1842 9334 5.6.2 Stratified Sampling Divide population into groups, then sample from each group. Example: - Male / Female - Region - Age group Used to ensure representation. 5.6.3 Systematic Sampling Select every k-th element. Example: Every 10th customer. 5.6.4 Cluster Sampling Select entire groups randomly. Example: Choose 5 stores and survey all customers there. 5.7 Sampling Bias Bias occurs when the sample does not represent the population. Example: Survey only online users → ignores offline customers. In machine learning: If training data is biased, the model becomes biased. Real-world example: Facial recognition systems failing due to non-diverse training data. Bias leads to systematic error. 5.8 Types of Errors 5.8.1 Sampling Error Difference between sample statistic and population parameter. Unavoidable but measurable. 5.8.2 Non-Sampling Error Data entry mistakes Poor survey design Measurement error Often more dangerous than sampling error. 5.9 Business Case Study Imagine an online retailer. They survey only customers who purchased in the last week. Is this sample representative? No. Inactive customers are ignored. Marketing decisions based on this data may be flawed. 5.10 ML Dataset Bias Example Suppose you train a loan approval model using: Mostly urban applicants Few rural applicants The model learns patterns biased toward urban behavior. Result: Unfair decisions. Statistics teaches us: Data collection quality determines model fairness. 5.11 Why This Chapter Matters Most analytical errors do not come from complex math. They come from: Poor sampling Biased data Misunderstood measurement scales If data is wrong, analysis will be wrong. Garbage in → garbage out. 5.12 Summary In this chapter we learned: Types of data Measurement scales Population vs sample Sampling techniques Bias and errors Business implications Machine learning fairness connection Next: Descriptive statistics.

6 Chapter 3: Descriptive Statistics Descriptive statistics answers the question: “What does our data look like?” Before building models, we must understand the structure of data. 6.1 Create Sample Data To make this chapter self-contained, we define data here. sales <- c(120, 135, 150, 98, 175, 142) category <- c("Electronics", "Clothing", "Electronics", "Groceries", "Clothing", "Electronics") 6.2 What Is Descriptive Statistics? Descriptive statistics summarizes and visualizes data. It does NOT make predictions about populations. It answers: What is the average? How spread out is the data? What values occur most often? What does the distribution look like?
7 Measures of Central Tendency 7.1 Mean (Average) 7.2 Median 7.3 Mode

7 Measures of Central Tendency 7.1 Mean (Average) \[ \bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n} \] mean(sales) ## [1] 136.6667 The mean is the balance point of data. 7.2 Median median(sales) ## [1] 138.5 Median is resistant to outliers. sales_with_outlier <- c(sales, 1000) mean(sales_with_outlier) ## [1] 260 median(sales_with_outlier) ## [1] 142 Notice how the mean changes dramatically, but the median does not. 7.3 Mode table(category) ## category ## Clothing Electronics Groceries ## 2 3 1 Mode is the most frequent value. For categorical data, mode is extremely useful.
8 Comparing Mean and Median Mean ≈ Median → symmetric data Mean > Median → right skew Mean < Median → left skew
9 Measures of Dispersion 9.1 Range 9.2 Variance 9.3 Standard Deviation 9.4 Coefficient of Variation

9 Measures of Dispersion Central tendency shows center. Dispersion shows variability. 9.1 Range range(sales) ## [1] 98 175 diff(range(sales)) ## [1] 77 Range depends only on extreme values. 9.2 Variance \[ s^2 = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1} \] var(sales) ## [1] 690.2667 Variance measures average squared deviation. 9.3 Standard Deviation \[ s = \sqrt{s^2} \] sd(sales) ## [1] 26.27293 Low SD → stable data High SD → volatile data 9.4 Coefficient of Variation \[ CV = \frac{s}{\bar{x}} \] sd(sales) / mean(sales) ## [1] 0.1922409 Used for comparing variability across scales.

10 Frequency Distribution 10.1 Categorical table(category) ## category ## Clothing Electronics Groceries ## 2 3 1 10.2 Numerical (Histogram) hist(sales, col="lightblue", main="Sales Distribution", xlab="Sales", ylab="Frequency")
11 Bar Chart barplot(table(category), col="steelblue", main="Category Distribution")
12 Boxplot boxplot(sales, col="orange", main="Sales Boxplot") Boxplot shows: Median Quartiles Outliers
13 Shape of Distribution 13.1 Simulate Right Skew 13.2 Simulate Normal Distribution

13 Shape of Distribution Distribution shape matters. 13.1 Simulate Right Skew set.seed(123) right_skew <- rexp(1000) hist(right_skew, col="red", main="Right Skewed Distribution") 13.2 Simulate Normal Distribution normal_data <- rnorm(1000) hist(normal_data, col="green", main="Normal Distribution") Understanding shape helps in: Feature transformation Log scaling Model assumptions
14 Business Interpretation Company A: Mean = 1M SD = 50K Company B: Mean = 1M SD = 500K Both have same mean. But B is riskier. Descriptive statistics reveals risk.
15 Descriptive Statistics in Machine Learning 15.1 Standardization

15 Descriptive Statistics in Machine Learning Before training models: Check distribution Detect outliers Standardize features Identify skewness 15.1 Standardization scaled_sales <- scale(sales) scaled_sales ## [,1] ## [1,] -0.63436659 ## [2,] -0.06343666 ## [3,] 0.50749327 ## [4,] -1.47173048 ## [5,] 1.45904315 ## [6,] 0.20299731 ## attr(,"scaled:center") ## [1] 136.6667 ## attr(,"scaled:scale") ## [1] 26.27293 Standardization ensures: Mean = 0 Standard deviation = 1 Critical for: Logistic Regression SVM Neural Networks K-means
